fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 1
fields.description: Numerical sets: real numbers, ordering and completeness; complex numbers: algebraic and trigonometric form, De Moivre theorems, n-th roots. Real functions of one real variable: domain, codomain, graph; elementary functions; composition of functions, invertibility and inverse function; monotonic, symmetric, periodic functions; sequences. Limits and continuity: main properties, indeterminate forms, rate of growth, monotone convergence, Weierstrass theorem, intermediate value theorem. Derivative: derivation rules, applications, differential and linear approximation, Fermat, Lagrange, De L'Hospital theorems; higher order derivatives; Taylor's formula, local approximation by polynomials, convex functions, maxima and minima, graph of functions. Integral of one variable functions: definite integral, main properties and applications; primitives, fundamental theorem of calculus, integration rules. Curves in R3. Numerical series; Taylor' series. Complex exponential function.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF COMPUTER SCIENCE
fields.description: Overview of computers and programming: functional description of an elementary computer, algorithms, programming languages, compilers, operating systems and networks. Encoding of the information, boolean operators and fundamental theorems. Programming language concepts using the C or C++ language: data abstraction and the use of types, control structures for the execution of a sequence of statements. Top-down design with functions, parameter passing among functions, local and global variables and the recursive programming. File management using operating system services. Translation of C or C++ programs into assembly language. Introduction to system programming.

fields.name: BUSINESS ECONOMICS AND ORGANIZATION
fields.description: Firms: objectives, typologies, ownership and control. General accounting: functions, content and classification of financial statements; liquidity and profitability. Long-run decisions (investment analysis): cost of capital, cash flows, Net Present Value, other assessment methods. Analysis of markets: demand, cost structure, perfect competition, other market structures. Cost accounting: cost typologies, cost analysis and allocation, short-run decisions, budgeting. Business organization: definitions, elements of organization design. Examples and applications from the ICT industries.

fields.name: PHYSICS
fields.description: Physical quantities and measurements.. Kinematics of a point particle. Newtonian dynamics, forces, study of motion. Work and energy. Dynamics in non-inertial reference frames. Elementary interactions between masses and electrical charges. Dynamics of particle systems and rigid bodies. Elements fluid mechanics Thermodynamical systems. The first end the second principles of thermodynamics. Kinetic theory of gases.

fields.name: GEOMETRY AND LINEAR ALGEBRA
fields.description: Vectors. Analytic geometry in cartesian 2 and 3 dimensions. Matrices; linear maps and systems; eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Euclidean spaces Rn. Conics and quadric surfaces.

fields.name: BASIC CIRCUIT THEORY
fields.description: Introduction to basic electric quantities. Kirchhoff Laws. Resistive one-port elements. Element constraints. Electric Power. Solution of simple circuits. Two-port elements. Controlled sources. Special two-port elements. Matrix representation. Analysis of resistive circuits: general methods, superposition principle. Thevenin and Norton equivalent one-ports. Dynamic components: capacitors, inductors, coupled inductors. Linear first order dynamic circuits (RC and RL). Sinusoidal steady state: phasor analysis, impedance and admittance, power, applications (resonance, maximum power transfer, impedance matching, power factor). Elementary three-phase circuits. Magnetic circuits (magnetic flux, reluctance) and real transformers. Electromagnetic fields theory: electrostatic fields and slow time-varying fields. Faraday's law and Ampere's law (integral form). Gauss' law. Conservation of charge.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 2 (FOR AUTOMATION ENGENEERING)
fields.description: Functions of several variables: limits, continuity, gradient, differentiability and linear approximation, higher order derivatives, Taylor's formula; free optimization. Multiple integrals in R2 and R3 : iterated integrals, change of variables. Curves in R2 e in R3: regularity, tangent vector, normal plane, length. Line integrals: work of a vector field, conservative vector fields, potential function. Ordinary differential equations: initial value problem. Separable variables. Linear differential equations: superposition principle, general solution. 1st order linear equations. 2nd order linear equations with constant coefficients. Power series. Taylor series. Exponential and trigonometric series in the complex field. Fourier series.

fields.name: THERMODYNAMICS AND HEAT TRANSFER
fields.description: Introduction to applied thermodynamics, first and second principle of thermodynamics and balance equations for closed and open systems. Properties of substances and processes, in particular models of ideal gas and ideal liquid. Basic heat transfer with outlines of fluid dynamics. Conduction, introduction to forced and natural convection, radiation. Heat exchangers: classification and basic design. Energy sources classification, consumption and reserves. The role of fluid machines in energy conversion. Classification and fundamental principles. Hydraulic machines and plants, cavitation, NPSH, outlines of control. Main direct and reverse thermodynamic cycles. Thermal machines: compressors, turbines, reciprocating engines. Power plants and components. Refrigerating machines and plants, heat pumps.

fields.name: INFORMATION SYSTEMS
fields.description: Single computer based control: interrupt mechanism, I/O techniques (polling, interrupt, direct memory access), OS structure, tasks and their management, scheduling. Real-time scheduling algorithms: real-time problem, mathematical formulation and optimality criteria, scheduling algorithms for aperiodic tasks, scheduling algorithms for periodic tasks, scheduling algorithms for mixed tasks, algorithms for overload management. Computer network based control: distributed control systems, network topologies, network structure, ISO/OSI protocols, Foundation FieldBus and Profibus, real-time on communication networks, real-time Ethernet, examples of real-time systems, scheduling in communication networks. Computer synchronization: inner synchronization and outer synchronization. Developing software applications: software engineering, software cycle, requirements analysis, specification methodologies, UML and state-chart.

fields.name: TELECOMMUNICATION NETWORKS
fields.description: The aim of the course is to prepare the students to understand the problems related to the transport of information through TLC networks. The principal concepts of services and networks will be presented. The traditional networks for telephony and for data will be examined. The focus of the course will be set to the communication protocols and the transport mechanism of information in presence of noisy connections. The most advanced networks both circuit switched, such as ISDN ,and packet switched such as Internet will be examined. The course includes a laboratory activity based on the teaching of the principles of discrete events simulation applied to the study of packed switched networks.

fields.name: BASIC CONTROL ENGINEERING
fields.description: Introduction to systems and control engineering. Oriented systems; nondynamic systems; dynamic systems: state-space and input-output forms; equilibria; tangent linear model at an operating point. Time-domain analysis of linear time-invariant systems; the stability problem: stability of motion vs. system stability; stability criteria; canonic responses. Basic signal analysis: Laplace transform, Heaviside method and dominant poles; Fourier transforms. Frequency-domain analysis of linear time-invariant systems; transfer functions; canonic decomposition and system stabilizability; realization of a transfer function; analysis of systems described by a block-diagram; frequency response. Control problems: an overview. Industrial regulators; empirical tuning rules. Linear time-invariant control systems; stability and precision analysis; performance specifications. Basic control system design in the frequency domain; model-based tuning of industrial regulators. Nonelementary control architectures: feedforward control, cascade control.

fields.name: MECHANICAL SYSTEMS MODELLING
fields.description: Planar kinematics and dynamics: Kinematics and dynamics of a single rigid body and of multi body systems; The Principle of d`Alembert, The Principle of Virtual Work, Lagrange`s Equations. Contact phenomena and fluid and solid interaction: basic concepts of tribology (static and dynamic friction, rolling resistance); basics of fluid and structure interaction: aerodynamic and hydrodynamic forces. Machine dynamics: Modelling of machines: motors, transmission, loads; power flows. Characteristics of motors. Steady state and transient motion. Vibrating n degree of freedom systems: Single d.o.f vibrating system: free and forced motion, frequency response. 2-n d.o.f vibrating system: free and forced motion, frequency response. Modal approach. Non conservative force fields: Systems subjected to non-conservative forces, static, dynamic and flutter instability.

fields.name: INTRODUCTION TO ELECTRONICS
fields.description: The course provides the students with a basic understanding both of electronic circuits (analog and digital) and of devices. Topics covered in the subject include: - Signals: acquisition and processing; sources and sensors; time domain and frequency domain analysis. - Circuits: transfer function, amplification and attenuation, input and ouptput impedance, circuit cascading. - Electronic devices: semiconductors, pn-junction diode, MOS transistor. - Digital electronics: CMOS logic, volatile and non-volatile memories. - Analog electronics: MOS single-stage amplifiers, MOS differential stage, operational amplifier, negative feedback, inverting and non-inverting amplifier, input and output impedance, current conveyors, summer, differential amplifiers, integrators, differentiators, frequency response and stability. - Analog to digital conversion: sampling theorem, sample&hold circuits, A/D converters, D/A converters. The focus of the subject is twofold: both understanding the basic concepts that drive the operation of an electronic circuit and understanding the impact of non-idealities of real components on the circuit performances. This course is not intended to develop a specific skill in electronics, but rather to give the student a rather broad view of the overall aspects of electronics. The breadth of topics covered in this course makes it useful both for the students who intend to graduate after the first three years and for the students who want to specialize in the field of electronics.

fields.name: ELECTRICAL MACHINE AND DRIVES
fields.description: Principles of electromechanical conversion. Electrical properties of conductive, insulating and magnetic materials Mutual inductors and industrial transformers: mathematical models. Phasor theory of rotating machines: mathematical models of isotropic machines. Steady-state analysis of synchronous and asynchronous machines. Electrical Drives: foundamentals and swtiching devices.

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: Questo credito completa i 9 CFU dell'insegnamento di MACCHINE ELETTRICHE E AZIONAMENTI (cod. 085742), svolto dallo stesso docente.Per i dettagli si rimanda alla scheda di tale insegnamento.

fields.name: MEASURES AND STRUMENTATIONS
fields.description: The course provides basic knowledge on metrology and calculation of measurement uncertainty. It also describes the operating principles of measurement instrumentation with an introduction to sensors and interface electronics. In the course laboratories the students learn to use oscilloscopes and to program in LabVIEW language, for data acquisition and implementation of simple systems of measurement and actuation.

fields.name: DISCRETE EVENT SYSTEMS
fields.description: The course aims at providing the methodological and practical foundations to deal with the basic automation systems for machines and industrial plants. Basic modelling and analysis techniques of discrete event systems with Petri nets will be considered. Also basic implementation of logic control with PLC in typical industrial applications will be investigated, with special attention to the discrete manufacturing field.

fields.name: PROCESS CONTROL
fields.description: The aim of the course is to deepen the study of automatic control systems, presenting advanced schemes and design techniques for both analog and digital control systems. Specific concepts, methods and tools for modeling and control of industrial processes are also discussed.

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: Questo modulo da 1 CFU completa i 7 CFU dell'insegnamento di Controllo dei processi (088692), svolto dallo stesso docente. All'interno del modulo vengono svolte alcune attività didattiche integrative (esercitazioni e laboratori) a corredo della parte del corso principale dedicata al Controllo dei processi industriali.

fields.name: INDUSTRIAL PLANTS AND PRODUCTION MANAGEMENT
fields.description: The objective of the course is to provide the students with the basic knowledge on the design and management of production systems. The course program is organized in the following topics: process representation techniques; performance measures and analysis of production systems; design methods for fabrication and assembly systems; economic evaluation for replacements / building of plants; phases of the production planning and control (PPC) process; costs relevant for production management; models for aggregate planning; models for stock management; materials requirements planning (MRP); operational scheduling and real time control; Japanese production methods (JIT).

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: Obiettivo Questo credito completa i 9 CFU dell'insegnamento di Impianti industriali e gestione della produzione (codice insegnamento 088694), svolto dallo stesso docente. Per i dettagli si rimanda alla scheda di tale insegnamento.

fields.name: ROBOTICS
fields.description: Introduction to robotics. Direct kinematics. Denavit ? Hartenberg notation. Inverse kinematics. Differential kinematics. Statics. Geometrical and analytical Jacobian matrix. Singularities. Algorithms for kinematics inversion. Statics. Direct and inverse dynamics. Closed form mathematical models. Examples. Simulation. Trajectory planning in joint space and in operational space. Centralized control: computed torque. Independent joint control (position servomechanisms). Torsional flexibility and friction. Eteroceptive sensors. Eteroceptive sensor based control. Hardware and software architectures for robot control.

fields.name: INTERNSHIP
fields.description: A period spent in a company or in a R&D laboratory or in a technical-oriented organization, which aims at introduce students to the problems of professional activity and to practice their academic knowledge.

fields.name: DATA BASES 1
fields.description: This course aims at communicating to students two basic abilities: designing and querying databases. After a brief introduction dedicated to data models and formal languages for databases, the course turns to the description of relational systems. Using SQL both as a query and data manipulation language, we show its use as a means for delivering relational applications. Next, we illustrate the Entity-Relationship model as an instrument for conceptual database design, discussing how the design process takes place and the quality requirements of design results.

fields.name: PROBABILITY AND STATISTICS
fields.description: The aim of the course is to present the basic probabilistic models and statistical techniques to address engineering problems related to random phenomena. Topics covered include: probability spaces, random variables and random vectors and their probability distributions. Conditional distribution and conditional expectation. Introduction to stochastic processes. Limiting theorems. Sampling distributions for Gaussian populations. Elements of estimation theory and testing statistical hypothesis. Introduction to nonparametric statistical methods.

fields.name: INTERNSHIP
fields.description: A period spent in a company or in a R&D laboratory or in a technical-oriented organization, which aims at introduce students to the problems of professional activity and to practice their academic knowledge.

fields.name: GENERAL CHEMISTRY
fields.description: Basis concepts: elements and compounds, chemical formulae, mole, simple reactions, stoichiometry. Atomic structure: nucleus and electrons. Electronic structure of atoms and the periodic system. The chemical bond: Ionic bonding: crystal structure and properties of ionic compounds. Covalent bonding: molecules and covalent solids. The metallic bond: conductors and semiconductors. States of matter: description of the gaseous state by the ideal-gas equation of state and of solids and liquids by phase diagrams. Chemical thermodynamics: First and second principles of thermodynamics. Enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy state functions, and their application to the calculation of the heat, spontaneity and equilibrium conditions of chemical reactions. Chemical kinetics: reaction rate. The molecular collision model of chemical reactions. Parameters affecting reaction rates. Catalysts. Reactions and equilibria in aqueous solutions: Acids, bases and acid-base equilibria. Autoprotolysis of water and the pH. Red-ox reactions. Electrochemical cells, electromotive force, standard reduction potentials, electrolysis.

fields.name: ELEMENTS OF FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS AND INTEGRAL TRANSFORMS
fields.description: Elements of Functional Analysis: vectorial and normed spaces; sequences and series in normed spaces; linear operators; Lebesgue integral on R; spaces C0[a, b], L1 (R),L2 (R) , L'(R); convergence of sequences and series on L1 (R) on L2 (R). Fourier Transform on L1 (R): main properties in time-domain and in frequency-domain, the Riemann-Lebesgue theorem; convolution; Fourier transform of convolution; the inversion formula on L1(R);the Plancherel equality on L1 (R)' L2 (R); the space S(R ) of rapidly decreasing functions. Distributions: the space D'(R ) of distributions on R ; main operations on D'(R); the Dirac impulse ; distributions with compact support; convolution; the space S'(R) of tempered distributions; Fourier transform on S'(R). Time-invariant linear operators on S'(R); filters theorem; impulse response; applications to linear differential and convolution equations. Band limited signals: the sampling theorem on L2 (R). Laplace Transform: analiticity; main properties; Laplace transform of the Dirac impulse; applications to causal filters; transfer function.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF OPERATIONS RESEARCH
fields.description: The course covers some of the fundamental methods of Operations Research that play a central role in solving a variety of complex decision-making problems. Particular attention is devoted to modeling and algorithmic issues. The main topics include: graph and network optimization, linear programming, integer programming, and an introduction to non linear programming.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS I AND GEOMETRY
fields.description: Basics of logic and set theory. Integer, rational, real, complex numbers. Planar and spatial vectors; straight lines and planes. Matrices and determinants; methods for solving linear systems; eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Sequences. Real functions of one real variable: limits, continuity, derivative and differential, monotone and convex functions, maxima and minima, Taylor's formula. The Riemann integral and integration methods.

fields.name: PHYSICS I
fields.description: Introduction to Physics. Kinematics and Dynamics of a Material Point. Kinetic Energy and Work. Potential Energy and Conservation of Energy. Gravitation. Oscillations. Systems of Particles and dynamics of a Rigid Body. Collisions. Hydrostatics. Introduction to Thermodynamics. Temperature, Heat, and Work. First Law of Thermodynamics. Second Law of Thermodynamics. Entropy.

fields.name: CHEMISTRY A
fields.description: Basis concepts: elements and compounds, chemical formulae, mole, simple reactions, stoichiometry. Atomic structure: nucleus and electrons. Electronic structure of atoms and the periodic system. The chemical bond: Ionic bonding: crystal structure and properties of ionic compounds. Covalent bonding: molecules and covalent solids. The metallic bond: conductors and semiconductors. States of matter: description of the gaseous state by the ideal-gas equation of state and of solids and liquids by phase diagrams. Chemical thermodynamics: First and second principles of thermodynamics. Enthalpy, entropy and Gibbs free energy state functions, and their application to the calculation of the heat, spontaneity and equilibrium conditions of chemical reactions. Chemical kinetics: reaction rate. The molecular collision model of chemical reactions. Parameters affecting reaction rates. Catalysts. Reactions and equilibria in aqueous solutions: Acids, bases and acid-base equilibria. Autoprotolysis of water and the pH. Red-ox reactions. Electrochemical cells, electromotive force, standard reduction potentials, electrolysis.

fields.name: INFORMATICS B
fields.description: Overview of computers and programming: functional description of an elementary computer, algorithms, programming languages, compilers, operating systems and networks. Encoding of the information, boolean operators and binary representation of numbers and characters. Programming language concepts using the C language: data abstraction and the use of types (particularly: array, struct and pointers), control structures (conditions, selection and loops) for the execution of a sequence of statements. Subprograms: functions and procedures. Top-down design of programs (using also subprograms). Parameter passing among subprograms, local and global variables and the recursive programming. Dynamic data types using pointers. File management using operating system services.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS II
fields.description: Functions of several real variables (scalar fields): continuity, gradient, differentiability. Maxima and minima. Implicit functions. Lagrange multipliers. Double and triple integrals. Curves in 2-D and 3-D, surfaces in 3-D. Line and surface integrals of a scalar field. Vector fields in 2-D and 3-D: rotation and divergence; line integral of a vector field; potential function and conservative fields; Gauss' and Stokes' theorems. Ordinary differential equations: initial value problems; solutions of first-order equations, of higher-order linear equations, etc.

fields.name: PHYSICS II
fields.description: Coulomb's Law. Electric field and potential. Gauss's Law. Electric field energy. Electrostatic in conductors and dielectrics. Electric current and Ohm's Law. Lorentz's force. The magnetostatic field and the laws of Laplace. Ampere's theorem. Magnetic field energy. The magnetism in matter. Law of electromagnetic induction. Displacement current and Maxwell-Faraday's law. Maxwell's equations and electromagnetic field. Electromagnetic waves.

fields.name: ECONOMY AND BUSINESS MANAGEMENT B
fields.description: Firms: objectives, typologies, ownership and control. General accounting: functions, content and classification of financial statements; liquidity and profitability. Long-run decisions (investment analysis): cost of capital, cash flows, Net Present Value, other assessment methods. Analysis of markets: demand, cost structure, perfect competition, other market structures. Cost accounting: cost typologies, cost analysis and allocation, short-run decisions, budgeting. Business organization: definitions, elements of organization design.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 1
fields.description: Numerical sets: real numbers, ordering and completeness; complex numbers: algebraic and trigonometric form, De Moivre theorems, n-th roots. Real functions of one real variable: domain, codomain, graph; elementary functions; composition of functions, invertibility and inverse function; monotonic, symmetric, periodic functions; sequences. Limits and continuity: main properties, indeterminate forms, rate of growth, monotone convergence, Weierstrass theorem, intermediate value theorem. Derivative: derivation rules, applications, differential and linear approximation, Fermat, Lagrange, De L'Hospital theorems; higher order derivatives; Taylor's formula, local approximation by polynomials, convex functions, maxima and minima, graph of functions. Integral of one variable functions: definite integral, main properties and applications; primitives, fundamental theorem of calculus, integration rules. Curves in R3. Numerical series; Taylor' series. Complex exponential function.

fields.name: FOUNDATIONS OF CHEMISTRY FOR ELECTRONICS
fields.description: Atomic theory. Stoichiometry. Atoms and molecules. Physical and chemical periodicity. Metallic bonding and alloys. Chemical bonding and modern electronics. Shape and intermolecular interactions. Supramolecular chemistry. Chemical reactivity: Thermodynamics and kinetics. The principles of chemical equilibrium. Electrochemistry: Batteries, corrosion, fuel cells, and membrane potentials. Coordination chemistry: gems, magnetization metals and membranes. Organic chemistry: The carbon age. Alkanes, Alkenes, and Alkynes. Benzene and aromaticity. Functional groups. Polymers.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF COMPUTER SCIENCE
fields.description: Overview of computers and programming: functional description of an elementary computer, algorithms, programming languages, compilers, operating systems and networks. Encoding of the information, boolean operators and fundamental theorems. Programming language concepts using the C or C++ language: data abstraction and the use of types, control structures for the execution of a sequence of statements. Top-down design with functions, parameter passing among functions, local and global variables and the recursive programming. File management using operating system services. Translation of C or C++ programs into assembly language. Introduction to system programming.

fields.name: GEOMETRY AND LINEAR ALGEBRA
fields.description: Vectors. Analytic geometry in cartesian 2 and 3 dimensions. Matrices; linear maps and systems; eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Euclidean spaces Rn. Conics and quadric surfaces.

fields.name: PHYSICS
fields.description: Physical quantities and measurements.. Kinematics of a point particle. Newtonian dynamics, forces, study of motion. Work and energy. Dynamics in non-inertial reference frames. Elementary interactions between masses and electrical charges. Dynamics of particle systems and rigid bodies. Elements fluid mechanics Thermodynamical systems. The first end the second principles of thermodynamics. Kinetic theory of gases.

fields.name: BUSINESS ECONOMICS AND ORGANIZATION
fields.description: Firms: objectives, typologies, ownership and control. General accounting: functions, content and classification of financial statements; liquidity and profitability. Long-run decisions (investment analysis): cost of capital, cash flows, Net Present Value, other assessment methods. Analysis of markets: demand, cost structure, perfect competition, other market structures. Cost accounting: cost typologies, cost analysis and allocation, short-run decisions, budgeting. Business organization: definitions, elements of organization design. Examples and applications from the ICT industries.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 2 (FOR STUDENTS IN INFORMATION ENGINEERING)
fields.description: Real functions of two or several variables: limits, continuity, level curves and surfaces, gradient, differentiability and linear approximation, higher order derivatives, Taylor's formula; free optimization; constrained optimization, Lagrange multipliers. Linear differential equations: 1st order and 2nd order equations, superposition principle, structure of general solution, existence and uniqueness for the initial value problem, solution techniques. Fourier series: pointwise convergence, amplitude spectrum. Double and triple integrals: properties and applications, formulae of reduction, change of variables (polar, cylindrical, spherical coordinates). Curves in the space: regularity, tangent straight line, normal plane. Line integrals: length of a curve, work of a vector field, conservative vector fields, potential function. One topic between a) Surfaces in R3: area, surface integrals, flow of a vector field through a surface; curl and divergence theorems in the plane and in the space. b) Differential linear systems: structure of general solution, existence and uniqueness for the initial value problem.

fields.name: ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS AND OPTICS
fields.description: Electrostatic phenomena and their description. Stationary electric current. Magnetic phenomena and their description. Electromagnetic induction phenomena. Electric and magnetic properties of matter. Maxwell equations and electromagnetic field propagation. Interaction between radiation and matter. Light waves and light propagation. Image formation and geometrical optics. Dispersion of light. Interference. Diffraction. Polarization of light.

fields.name: BASIC CIRCUIT THEORY
fields.description: Introduction to basic electric quantities. Kirchhoff Laws. Resistive one-port components. Voltage-Current descriptive function. Electric Power. Solution of simple circuits. Two-ports. Controlled sources. Special two-ports. Matrix representation. Analysis of resistive circuits: general methods, superposition principle. Thevenin and Norton equivalent one-ports. Dynamic components: capacitors, inductors, coupled inductors. Linear dynamic circuits: first order (RC and RL) and second order (RLC). Sinusoidal steady state: phasor method, immitance and impedance, power, applications (resonance, maximum power transfer, impedance adaptation, power factor correction). Fundamentals of elctromechanic transformations.

fields.name: BASIC CONTROL ENGINEERING
fields.description: Introduction to control problems. Dynamic systems: time-domain description of linear systems, transfer function and step response, frequency response, block diagrams, linearization of nonlinear systems. Analysis and synthesis of single-input-single-output feedback control systems: stability and precision, robustness, trial and error techniques for regulator design, industrial PID regulators. Non elementary control architectures. Digital control: control system structure, converters, continuous-time and discrete-time analysis and synthesis.

fields.name: INTRODUCTION TO ELECTRONICS
fields.description: The course provides the students with a basic understanding of electronic circuits (both analog and digital). Topics covered in the subject include: - Signals: sources and sensors; time domain and frequency domain analysis. - Circuits: transfer function, amplification and attenuation, input and ouptput impedance, circuit cascading. - Electronic devices: pn-junction diode, MOS transistor. - Digital electronics: CMOS inverter and CMOS logic gates. - Analog electronics: MOS single-stage amplifiers, MOS differential stage, operational amplifier, negative feedback, inverting and non-inverting amplifier, input and output impedance, current conveyors, summing amplifiers, differential amplifiers, integrators, differentiators, frequency response and stability. - Analog to Digital and Digital to Analog conversion: sampling theorem, sample&hold circuits, A/D converters, D/A converters. The focus of the subject is twofold: both understanding the basic concepts that drive the operation of an electronic circuit and understanding the impact of non-idealities of real components on the circuit performance. This course is not intended to develop a specific skill in electronics, but rather to provide a solid knowledge of the fundamentals of circuit analysis. The breadth of topics covered in this course makes it useful both for the students who are oriented for the Bachelor and for the students who want to specialize with a Master in the field of electronics.

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: Questo credito completa i 9CFU del Corso di Fondamenti di Elettronica tenuto dalla stessa docente alla cui scheda si rimanda per ogni dettaglio.

fields.name: ELECTRONIC DEVICES
fields.description: The course introduces the principles and the performances of the main semiconductor devices. The fundamentals of semiconductor physics are preliminary introduced. The PN diode, the metal-semiconductor contact, the BJTs, the JFET and the MOSFET are then discussed as well as the VLSI CMOS structures. Basics of III-V semiconductors and devices are then introduced.

fields.name: PRINCIPLES OF COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE
fields.description: The course aims at introducing thr basic principles and components of the computer architecture, following a teaching path that starts from the programming level and operating system level, studied in the previous course, down to logic design and the gates that constitute the basic elements of the hardware components.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF SIGNALS AND TRANSMISSION
fields.description: This module presents the fundamental theory on the transmission of analogue and digital signals. We consider the fundamentals of probability theory and random processes (including thermal and shot noise). We study time and frequency characteristics of deterministic and random signals, of linear time-invariant and time-variant filters which model a communication channel. Finally, we consider the transmission of analogue and digital signals in baseband and passband channels, with analogue and digital modulations, in amplitude, phase and frequency.

fields.name: ANALOGIC ELECTRONICS
fields.description: Use of transistors (MOSFET and BJT) in analog circuits: common source (emitter) amplifiers, voltage and current buffers, current mirrors, differential stages. Responce non-linearities and harmonic distorsions. Frequency behaviour of analog circuits and design rules to extend their bandwidth (source resistance, cascode configuration, current mode approach). Feedback circuits analysis and design: gain, bandwidth, linearity, input and output impedence. Fundamental of noise generated by electronc components and noise analysis of analog circuits.

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: ObiettiviL'insegnamento si propone di fornire informazioni di complemento al corso di Elettronica Analogica da 9 crediti, in particolare focalizzando l'attenzione sui sistemi elettronici analogici complessi, costituiti da più stadi amplificanti in cascata   Programma delle lezioni e delle esercitazioni 1. CIRCUITI ELETTRONICI COMPLESSI (8 ore di lezione + 2 ore di esercitazione) Introduzione agli amplificatori a più stadi. Descrizione dei circuiti interni ad un Amplificatore Operazionale. Distorsione armonica nei circuiti a più stadi distorcenti. Risposta in frequenza e stabilità nei circuiti retroazionati a più stadi.  PrerequisitiI prerequisiti dell'insegnamento si possono trovare negli insegnamenti di Elettrotecnica, di Fondamenti di Elettronica, di Fondamenti di Automatica e di Elettronica Analogica (9 crediti).

fields.name: DIGITAL ELECTRONIC SYSTEMS
fields.description: Aim of the course is to provide fundamental principles of design and realization of electronic architectures for handling and processing of digital signals, in particular by means of FPGA and DSP configurable computing devices. At the end of course student should be provided with: i) awareness of methodologies for hardware-oriented design of acquisition, conditioning, analog-to-digital conversion and digital processing of signals; ii) skills to synthetize and implement processing architectures of digital signals in a programmable electronic device; iii) having knowledge of design flow principles of digital systems in FPGA and DSP electronic devices.

fields.name: FINAL EXAMINATION
fields.description: Obiettivi  Il modulo, offerto a valle dell'insegnamento Sistemi Elettronici Digitali tenuto dallo stesso docente, fornisce esempi applicativi delle tecniche fondamentali dell'elaborazione elettronica digitale dei segnali in situazioni sperimentali reali.   Programma delle lezioni e delle esercitazioni Contestualizzazione del problema; criteri di scelta tra possibili soluzioni; linee guida implementative; testing.

fields.name: THERMODYNAMICS AND HEAT TRANSFER
fields.description: Fundamentals of Thermodynamics: First Law for closed and open systems: internal energy and enthalpy. Second Law for closed and open systems: entropy. External and internal irreversibilities. Applied thermodynamics: turbine, pump, heater and cooler. Analysis of power generation and refrigeration systems. Heat transfer. Conduction: The Fourier law. Unidirectional steady conduction. Extended surfaces (Fins). The lumped capacitance model for unsteady conduction. Convection: basic principles of convection: forced and natural convection. Dimensional analysis and model theory. Correlations in forced and natural convection. Radiation: black body radiation. Heat transfer between black surfaces. Diffuse-gray surfaces. Application: heat exchanger, electronic cooling.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF MEASUREMENT
fields.description: Metrology: principles of measurements; reference standards and International System of units (SI); fundamental and secondary measurement units; units in linear and logarithmic scales; graphic representation of experimental data. Statistical analysis of measurement data: probability density function, mean, variance, correlated variables, and measurement uncertainty; compatibility between measurements and weighted mean value. Interpolation and regression of measurement data. Data acquisition systems: sampling and A/D conversion; characteristics and working principles of DACs and ADCs (speed, resolution, quantization uncertainty, number of equivalent bits); properties and use of DAQ systems; LabVIEW software for automated measurements. Instrumentation: digital voltmeters (differential and integrating) and multimeters (DMM); synthesized function generator; digital oscilloscope; basics of spectral measurements and spectrum analyzers. Applications: A pair of specific examples of measurements will be discussed in detail during exercises and experimentally verified during the Lab. activities.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF NUMERICAL ANALYSIS
fields.description: Errors in Numerical Processes: Stability and conditioning of numerical methods and algorithms. Numerical Solution of Linear Systems: Condition number and its influence on errors propagation. Direct methods: Gaussian elimination and matrix factorizations. Iterative procedures: Jacobi, Gauss Seidel, S.O.R. Solution of overdetermined linear systems by the Least-Squares method. Eigenvalues Approximation: The power method and the QR method. Solution of Nonlinear Equations: Iterative methods: bisection method, fixed-point iteration and Newton method for system of nonlinear equations. Zeros of polynomials. Approximation: Polynomial interpolation. Splines interpolation. Least-Squares approximation and data fitting. Numerical Integration: Newton-Cotes rules. Composite rules. Adaptive quadrature. The Solution of the Cauchy Problem for Ordinary Differential Equations: One step methods, Euler, trapezoidal rules and Runge-Kutta methods. Stability and convergence analysis. MATLAB software library.

fields.name: ELECTRICAL MACHINES
fields.description: This course deals with the principles of the electromechanical conversion. At first, the magnetic circuits and the Faraday`s law are analysed, showing the physical meaning of the auto and mutual inductance parameters. Then the magnetic, conducting and isolating materials, used in the electrical machines, are studied, showing their properties. The four principal electrical machines are studied: the transformer, the d.c. machine, the induction and the synchronous ones. The approach is the same for all of them, consisting in: the description of the constitution and of the operating elementary principle; the schematisation of the magnetic field lines inside the machine, introducing the concept of main and leakage fluxes; the analysis of the interaction between the magnetic fluxes and the electrical windings, deriving the representative equations and the equivalent electrical circuit of the machine; the methods for the parameters identification. As regards each machine, some fundamental aspects are described. As for the transformer, the voltage variation from a no-load to a load condition, the vector diagram, the short circuit current and the variable-frequency operation are considered. As for the rotating electrical machines, the dependence of the torque-speed curve on the constructive parameters is analysed, showing the operating condition as a motor, a generator and a brake. Static converters, used to feed the rotating electrical machines, are analysed. Finally, some motor control methods are described.

fields.name: MECHANICS
fields.description: The first part of the course is dedicated to the study of the kinematics of the rigid bodies in plane motion with geometry and algebra of vector solutions and complex numbers method. Arguments such the phenomenon of the contact between solids, as friction are introduced. The second part of the course deal with the dynamics of rigid bodies system in plane motion. General equations of dynamics are discussed and is introduced the D`Alambert principle. Work-Energy relations are treated in the study of the energy flow in a machine with the characterization of engine, transmission and utilizator. Concepts of steady and transient rate, direct and retrograde motion are discussed. For all the arguments the development of various numerical applications are provided.

fields.name: OPTOELECTRONICS
fields.description: The course has two purposes: to teach the basics principles of optoelectronics to students who will not specialize in this subject, and to give a broad knowledge of the field to students who, in the graduate studies, will study in deepth only some of these topics (e.g. lasers, detectors, systems,...). The course will give an emphasis to the applications, for students interested in utilizing specific devices or to design systems. For each topic will be discussed the physical and technological aspects more relevant to understand the behaviour and the limitations of devices and systems. The performances will be studied taking into account typical applications , with a critical discussion of possible alternatives. The students will learn which are the typical performances of specific devices and how to design simple applications choosing the appropriate components. Main topics are: light sources, both coherent (lasers) and incoherent; detectors sensitive to visible and near infrared radiation, for application in the field of optical communications and of instrumentation for optical measurement; principles of guided optical propagation and application to telecommunications.

fields.name: INTERNSHIP
fields.description: A period spent in a company or in a R&D laboratory or in a technical-oriented organization, which aims at introduce students to the problems of professional activity and to practice their academic knowledge.

fields.name: ELEMENTS OF FUNCTIONAL ANALYSIS AND INTEGRAL TRANSFORMS
fields.description: Elements of Functional Analysis: vectorial and normed spaces; sequences and series in normed spaces; linear operators; Lebesgue integral on R; spaces C0[a, b], L1 (R),L2 (R) , L'(R); convergence of sequences and series on L1 (R) on L2 (R). Fourier Transform on L1 (R): main properties in time-domain and in frequency-domain, the Riemann-Lebesgue theorem; convolution; Fourier transform of convolution; the inversion formula on L1(R);the Plancherel equality on L1 (R)' L2 (R); the space S(R ) of rapidly decreasing functions. Distributions: the space D'(R ) of distributions on R ; main operations on D'(R); the Dirac impulse ; distributions with compact support; convolution; the space S'(R) of tempered distributions; Fourier transform on S'(R). Time-invariant linear operators on S'(R); filters theorem; impulse response; applications to linear differential and convolution equations. Band limited signals: the sampling theorem on L2 (R). Laplace Transform: analiticity; main properties; Laplace transform of the Dirac impulse; applications to causal filters; transfer function.

fields.name: SOLID STATE ELECTRONICS
fields.description: Aim of the course is to provide a deep knowledge of the microscopic phenomena underlying the operation of electronic devices. The course consists of a first stage, aimed at introducing of quantum mechanics fundamentals and at illustrating the band theory for crystalline solids, and a second part aimed at studying the statistics of state population and the transport in metals and semiconductors. The electrical properties of semiconductors, including doping and conduction properties of semiconductors, transport processes (drift and diffusion), generation and recombination mechanisms, impact ionization and tunneling, are covered. The course include laboratory sessions for apprehending numerical techniques for computing wavefunctions of carrier and the associated transport in semiconductor devices.

fields.name: ELECTROMAGNETIC FIELDS
fields.description: Fundamental concepts, the Coulomb force and the electrostatic field, the electrostatic potential, capacitance, the Lorentz force and the magnetostatic field, inductance, Maxwell's equations in time and phasor form, plane waves, ideal and lossy transmission lines, matching networks. Advanced applications of electromagnetic fields.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 1
fields.description: Numerical sets: real numbers, ordering and completeness; complex numbers: algebraic and trigonometric form, De Moivre theorems, n-th roots. Real functions of one real variable: domain, codomain, graph; elementary functions; composition of functions, invertibility and inverse function; monotonic, symmetric, periodic functions; sequences. Limits and continuity: main properties, indeterminate forms, rate of growth, monotone convergence, Weierstrass theorem, intermediate value theorem. Derivative: derivation rules, applications, differential and linear approximation, Fermat, Lagrange, De L'Hospital theorems; higher order derivatives; Taylor's formula, local approximation by polynomials, convex functions, maxima and minima, graph of functions. Integral of one variable functions: definite integral, main properties and applications; primitives, fundamental theorem of calculus, integration rules. Curves in R3. Numerical series; Taylor' series. Complex exponential function.

fields.name: BUSINESS ECONOMICS AND ORGANIZATION
fields.description: Firms: objectives, typologies, ownership and control. General accounting: functions, content and classification of financial statements; liquidity and profitability. Long-run decisions (investment analysis): cost of capital, cash flows, Net Present Value, other assessment methods. Analysis of markets: demand, cost structure, perfect competition, other market structures. Cost accounting: cost typologies, cost analysis and allocation, short-run decisions, budgeting. Business organization: definitions, elements of organization design. Examples and applications from the ICT industries.

fields.name: FUNDAMENTALS OF COMPUTER SCIENCE
fields.description: Overview of computers and programming: functional description of an elementary computer, algorithms, programming languages, compilers, operating systems and networks. Encoding of the information, boolean operators and fundamental theorems. Programming language concepts using the C or C++ language: data abstraction and the use of types, control structures for the execution of a sequence of statements. Top-down design with functions, parameter passing among functions, local and global variables and the recursive programming. File management using operating system services. Translation of C or C++ programs into assembly language. Introduction to system programming.

fields.name: PHYSICS
fields.description: Physical quantities and measurements.. Kinematics of a point particle. Newtonian dynamics, forces, study of motion. Work and energy. Dynamics in non-inertial reference frames. Elementary interactions between masses and electrical charges. Dynamics of particle systems and rigid bodies. Elements fluid mechanics Thermodynamical systems. The first end the second principles of thermodynamics. Kinetic theory of gases.

fields.name: BASIC CIRCUIT THEORY
fields.description: Introduction to basic electric quantities. Kirchhoff Laws. Resistive one-port components. Voltage-Current descriptive function. Electric Power. Solution of simple circuits. Two-ports. Controlled sources. Special two-ports. Matrix representation. Analysis of resistive circuits: general methods, superposition principle. Thevenin and Norton equivalent one-ports. Dynamic components: capacitors, inductors, coupled inductors. Linear dynamic circuits: first order (RC and RL) and second order (RLC). Sinusoidal steady state: phasor method, immitance and impedance, power, applications (resonance, maximum power transfer, impedance adaptation, power factor correction). Fundamentals of elctromechanic transformations.

fields.name: GEOMETRY AND LINEAR ALGEBRA
fields.description: Vectors. Analytic geometry in cartesian 2 and 3 dimensions. Matrices; linear maps and systems; eigenvalues and eigenvectors. Euclidean spaces Rn. Conics and quadric surfaces.

fields.name: MATHEMATICAL ANALYSIS 2 (FOR STUDENTS IN INFORMATION ENGINEERING)
fields.description: Real functions of two or several variables: limits, continuity, level curves and surfaces, gradient, differentiability and linear approximation, higher order derivatives, Taylor's formula; free optimization; constrained optimization, Lagrange multipliers. Linear differential equations: 1st order and 2nd order equations, superposition principle, structure of general solution, existence and uniqueness for the initial value problem, solution techniques. Fourier series: pointwise convergence, amplitude spectrum. Double and triple integrals: properties and applications, formulae of reduction, change of variables (polar, cylindrical, spherical coordinates). Curves in the space: regularity, tangent straight line, normal plane. Line integrals: length of a curve, work of a vector field, conservative vector fields, potential function. One topic between a) Surfaces in R3: area, surface integrals, flow of a vector field through a surface; curl and divergence theorems in the plane and in the space. b) Differential linear systems: structure of general solution, existence and uniqueness for the initial value problem.

fields.name: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURES AND OPERATING SYSTEMS
fields.description: Parallel and concurrent programming models: processes and threads. The structure of Operating Systems: process management, virtual memory, file system structure and device drivers. Introduction to digital logic circuits: Boolean algebra and lgic gates, boolean function implementation and basic combinational circuits, basic sequential elements, memory organization. Functional subsystems: buses and interfacing. Processor microarchitecture: data path and control path, microcode. Microarchitecture design and performances: pipelining and cache memory. Instructution Set Architectural level (with a reference processor): instruction formats and addressing modes, assembly process and linking.

fields.name: PROBABILITY AND STATISTICS
fields.description: ObbiettiviScopo del corso e' quello di fornire all'allievo i modelli matematici e le tecniche statistiche di base per affrontare problemi ingegneristici inerenti ai fenomeni casuali. Probabilita' condizionata e indipendenza stocastica. Formule delle probabilita' totali e di Bayes, regola del prodotto. Prove di Bernoulli. Esempi ed applicazioni. 2. Variabili aleatorie. Variabili aleatorie e funzione di ripartizione. Variabili aleatorie discrete e assolutamente continue e loro funzioni di densita'. Valore atteso e varianza; deviazione standard. ``Failure rate''. Esempi di distribuzioni notevoli: distribuzione uniforme discreta, di Bernoulli, binomiale, geometrica, di Poisson, ipergeometrica, uniforme continua, esponenziale, gamma, normale; loro principali proprieta' e applicazioni. Funzione di una variabile aleatoria: metodo della funzione di ripartizione. Proprieta' di valore atteso e varianza. Momenti; cenni a distribuzioni senza momenti e a ``coda lunga''. Funzioni di vettori aleatori discreti e congiuntamente continui: metodo della funzione di ripartizione. Trasformazioni affini. Somma di variabili aleatorie; convoluzione discreta e continua. Somma di variabili aleatorie di Poisson indipendenti, di gamma indipendenti, di normali indipendenti. Valore atteso di una funzione di variabili aleatorie. Media campionaria, suo valore atteso e sua varianza; varianza campionaria e suo valore atteso. Legge debole e legge forte dei grandi numeri. Distribuzioni campionarie per popolazioni gaussiane. Distribuzione congiunta di media e varianza campionarie per un campione gaussiano. Distribuzioni chi-quadrato, t di Student, F di Fisher. 5. Teoria della stima. Statistiche e stimatori. Metodo dei momenti e metodo di massima verosimiglianza per la costruzione di stimatori puntuali. Errore quadratico medio. Proprieta' esatte e asintotiche degli stimatori: non distorsione, non distorsione asintotica, consistenza, normalita' asintotica. Intervalli di confidenza per media e varianza di popolazioni gaussiane. Esempi ed applicazioni.6. Verifica delle ipotesi. Ipotesi statistiche, semplici e composte; errori di primo e secondo tipo; regione critica, statistica test, livello di significativita' del test, funzione potenza, p-value. Test z, t, chi-quadro e F; altri esempi di test parametrici. Connessioni fra prova delle ipotesi e intervalli di confidenza. Metodi non parametrici. Test  chi-quadro di buon adattamento e di indipendenza. Test di Kolmogorov-Smirnov;  test di normalita'.
